job_title: ESL Instructor in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: Nice coworkers, who are like family.
cons: Low pay and wish there were benefits.

review_title: Best Place if you can adjust to change
job_title: Admissions Representative in Towson, MD
pros: Great Pay, benefits decent, open communication
cons: Alot of changes, departments not all on same page

job_title: SAHM in Palatine, IL
pros: People, some opportunity for advancement
cons: sometimes the reputation of for-profit education got in the way.

job_title: Program Manager/Business Analyst in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Able to grow in company
cons: Restructuring and merging always taking place

review_title: Can't find a job making more $ for what we do...
job_title: Admissions Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: High salaries for those who've been in the business/company for 5+ yrs (not so much for new employees). Great benefits package compared to the competition.
cons: Easily replaceable by others who will work for far less $ and that point is driven home daily. KU used to be a great place to work. Now, only the salary and benefits package are keeping me here. It went from a university to a sweatshop. Our goals are constantly increasing, but our salaries are stagnant. Favoritism and unequal opportunities abound, but everyone on a team has the same goal. So it doesn't matter if one advisor gets 20 good leads and another gets 2, you both have to have 20 enrollments to keep your job. We're not allowed to drum up our own business so you better hope you can take enough to get by (from those who are fed and aren't able to follow up like they should). There is enough business at the table for everyone to eat, but some are given steak while others get beans. Why can't we all have hamburgers?

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Great training program but long, 3 weeks long and very detailed.  When you hit the sales floor many of the things you learned in the training class didn't match up with the various floor managers way of doing things. But the Ass. Director was quick to let you know how he wants things done.
cons: The overall culture consisted of reverse racism.  If you are not Black or Hispanic then your chances of a promotion as close to none.  There was a lot of internal pettiness and one step out of line could have you setting in an "interrogation" type of interview with 3 to 4 managers demanding you confess your crime.   Which anyone could say something negative about you, without giving their name.  In this high pressure sales positions you need to watch your back.  Not a place I would recommend working do to the lack of stability within the company and the hostile working conditions.    This company laid off about the interior Financial Aid team and closed down multiple teams ( 20+ people per team) one day.  The next day they had a champagne toast for not getting laid off with the promise no one else would be laid off.  Then later walked 25 more people out the front door with security.

review_title: depends on position in the company
job_title: Program Manager in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Role is critical in determining your experience, can be very supportive.
cons: not every role allows for self actualization

job_title: Customer Service in Orlando, FL
pros: Only remote work is currently available
cons: Customer service is completely disorganized

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Free education, lifelong friendships , The training I recieved was the best however when I left efforts to coach and train had endedq
cons: I jumped ship last year as I witnessed every positive that had attracted me to KU become a negative. Management has made many unhealthy decisions that have depleted the organization of quality people. When you witness the best leaders and advisors  leaving  for other companies you know something is wrong. Many advisors have inflated salaries and  earn even  triple of what newer employees make even if the newer employee out performs. The  upside down salaries are known by all and is very demoralizing. Rules and policies change weekly and then change again. People are scared and confused of what happens next and most are seeking employment and searching for other jobs. All it takes is to visit the campus and see the empty parking lot and see rows of empty desks to know that this is not a growing organization. A very , very sad situation because this once was a thriving, happy environment full of loyal and happy advisors.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: You meet a lot of wonderful people who have years and years of experience in the industry who are more than willing to help you. There is definitely a since of team unity since every employee is assigned to a team which normally consists of the people you go through training with and maybe some veterans. Even though  you are on a specific team other people are still very willing to help. The culture is very much so that the advisors take care of one another and maybe a few associate directors are helpful. The compensation is great the pay and the benefits all kick in on the first day of training.
cons: The cons mainly lie with management. If you're lucky you will end up on a team where you have an associate director who is genuine and really cares about helping their team grow and learn. If you are like the majority you will unfortunately end up with an associate director who is more concerned about themselves than their team. Its a very numbers driven environment. You are really forced to take people who really are not aware or qualified for this level of education, not ready for an online environment, and the financial aspect of being enrolled at Kaplan University. The associate directors micromanage with an attitude of beating you down with negativity instead of teaching you how to improve. The directors of admissions are even worse. Their priority is numbers only and they have a very hands off approach to really helping employees succeed.

review_title: Great Company Vision with Misaligned Growth/Salary Opportunities
job_title: Senior Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Some really great people to work with.  I was able to perfect my craft, but only because I was self-driven to excel.  Opportunity to grow, but unfortunately capped.
cons:
1. Company core values changed so frequently that it was hard for them to stick and create a true company culture.
2. For some roles the work/life balance was weighing more on the work and less on the life 
3. Management was not consistent with managing employees on the same team and on the same role although KPI's were exactly the same, the inconsistency was unprofessional.  A lot of favortism

review_title: Good courses and good pay to treat students as customers.  N.B. Last year was 2009 but 2011 was the oldest option.
job_title: Online Faculty in Palm Beach, FL
pros: The courses in Humanities are very good in regard to content and presentation and the terms were short at ten weeks long.  The pay is leveled by degree and experience and went up to 2800.  If you can be enthusiastic about a for-profit educational corporation where the students are customers and the "brand" is all, then this is definitely for you.
cons: The program has the flaws of the for-profit educational institution; viz, they treat students as customers.  The staff treats faculty well but it is understood one will do what can be done to help the students "succeed," it's all about the cash flow and enrolling students.  The weekly one hour webinars are not bad but the students only receive five points so they have less interest.  Multiple discussion boards each week (at least two, sometimes three) and the demand that one posts at least eight times to each.  That's not bad but the expectation is that one will post 36+ times each week.  Tedious extra work to monitor student progress is not hard but does not enhance the position.  The staff does not back up faculty well and, generally, concentrates more on one student complaint in contrast to multiple good reviews.  Of course, this is the "student as customer" mentality.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Great group of co-workers. One giant family. Opportunity to obtain degree at no cost through Kaplan online.
cons: Pays less than competitors. Very slim opportunity for upward mobility.  A lot of pressure placed on the number of enrollments needed in a very clearly put "sales environment" without the pay.  No bonus or commission but you have expectations that need to be met. Management operates under under a very tight knit good old boys club where corporate politics will play a role on where you end up.

review_title: Another Call Center Masquerading as a University
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Training is very top notch and informative I felt very prepared for my role as an Admissions Advisor. The pay is good and you receive benefits and PTO from the first day, which you don't see very often from most companies. Finally, there is a cafeteria on site so you don't need to go out for lunch (1hr)
cons: Well after training and all the dog and pony shows...you come out into production. During the interview, I was told we are helping students improve their lives, which is true to a point. That changed when the manager informed us that "this is a sales job." They weren't wrong neither when they said that since if you didn't hit your targets it was strike one. If it happens again strike two, and finally strike three...Your'e Out!!! I've done lots of phone work before and to this day, that was one of the most stressful jobs I've ever had. Management has been known to play favorites, so if you're not on The A Team, then its a long ride uphill. Since then they have changed some things, so if you decide to interview ask lots of questions,

job_title: Associate Director of Admissions in Orlando, FL
pros: Excellent Product, a school with a curriculum rigerous and substanial provides real working knowledge for current and future professionals.  Great core group of management staff and advisors who truly care about our main mission "Changing Lives", as well as keeping it a great place to work. I have referred friends to Kaplan for both education and employment and I tell you there is no better feeling than to see you friends succeed.  Watching a friend walk across that stage knowing that school was the futherest thing from their minds years ago, now they are changing careers, getting a promotion or actually "Have a career now".  Or the communication from your employment referrals on they appreciate the opportunity, how they are outperforming their peers, how they are moving up within their departments. Refering the right people makes you feel good all the way around.
cons: Tough times create some uncomfortable situations.  Things have been lean and some tough decisions made. But as tough as those decisions have been, I believe it has put the company in a better position to grow. "Already seeing the positive results"

job_title: Admissions Advisor II in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Benefits on first day and free tuition. The best decision upper management ever made was firing my former manager in July 2012. He was the worst and most unhelpful manager I have ever encountered, yet had a huge ego. Upper management finally realized to fire him based on performance and that they shouldn't keep him based on where he was from. That same manager didn't even have a degree, yet his admissioins advisors were expected to have at least a bachelors.
cons:
Management constantly talks down to their employees and everyone is treated like a number. Job is a very low level inside sales job. You need to hit a certain quota every month which constantly changes and if you don't and your not one of managements favorites your fired. Some people are given good leads and some are assigned poor leads, your success will be determined by how much managers like you. Some admissions advisors job roles were changed back in July to
just simply answering the phone with no sales goals. They kept the same pay but had job security because how can you screw up answering the phone. Although many of these phone receptionists quit out of boredom. Constant layoffs and a feeling that you could get fired any day.

job_title: Management in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The pro's here are that the company does have some great people in high positions that do try and make a difference all the time. The training department is awesome and they really do get you ready to do the job. A lot of good solid people working here in the trenches.
cons: The cons are that there are just as many bad apples in high positions as the really good one's. There is favoritism and a lot of the time this determines who gets the "good leads" (the job is goal based), favoritism also decides who gets promoted. Performance will get you noticed, however "cozying up" to management is the only way to really excel here. Unfortunately it drives away top talent.

job_title: Student Accounts Representative in Plantation, FL
pros: The pros are.. the pay and benefits.
cons:
Management ..What management??   
Managers don't know how to manage or respect their employees.  Management and Human Resources work together to encourage bad behavior.  Managers do not receive training on how to deal with human beings and how not to show favoritism.  Bad review don't phase them either they only blame the employees.

Favoritism is rampant.  Management show who they like and dislike on the floor all day everyday.   I have never experienced anything like this where its all about who you know with all management across the board.  

There is a lot of talented and educated people they do not recognize or like because they obviously feel threatened by anyone who can read or write.  No chance of moving up the corporate ladder in this place ever unless you are bff's with someone at the top.

review_title: Kaplan is worried more about student reviews than anything else
job_title: ESL Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: Most of the students were amazing! Eager to learn and they were so helpful to eachothers needs as well. I really really loved my students.
cons: Some of the students were completely catered. They were on student visas and would come check in and leave the classroom for the rest of the day and never come back. Kaplan was more worried about negative reviews than reiterating to students that they were on student visas... AND they would expect very thorough reviews on students every 6 weeks- some on students who may have only been in my classroom for a couple days— and would not went to compensate for time spent on these reviews, I.e. would be called into management office explaining any logged time for reviews or lesson planning. Keep in mind—- Kaplan rarely employs full time teachers!!! You’re part time even if you’re basically working full time!

job_title: Admissions Advisor II in Orlando, FL
pros: Training was fun, good co-workers, and if you like talking on the phone, then you will enjoy your position.
cons: Micromanagement is rampant within Kaplan.  You literally have to set a status on your computer to let your direct manager know where you are.  Bathroom break?  Make sure you let someone know.  You are treated like you are in high school, but even then I had more freedom.  Also, management is extremely based on favoritism.  If your direct manager likes you, you can scoot by without problems.  But if they do not, you are constantly waiting to be "called into an office" or walked out the door.

review_title: Long Time Kaplan Employee - An Honest Assessment
job_title: Project Assistant in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Great people, stable company, good work atmosphere, excellent benefits, covered parking, on-site cafeteria.
cons: Little or no career path, tiny annual raises (no matter how much you excel at your job), top heavy management structure,  difficult to post or move around in the company, insanely complicated review process that takes up too much time and results in no action or plan,  the company is always crying poor, but the executives make gobs of money, and the workers sometimes get 1% raise (or zero some years).  Apparently, the only way to move up and earn more money is to go somewhere else. They have a good time off policy, but there is never a good time to use it.  The entire company is very, very understaffed, and very, very overworked.....and there is a lot of attrition because of it.

review_title: Kaplan is Great...It's this particular dept.
job_title: Support and Solutions Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: You have a job and free education.
cons: There are no schedules changes. They hired someone off the streets and gave them the schedules we asked for. You will take 70+ calls per day. You cannot take breaks if someone else is on break. You cannot have lunch with a coworker. You will be doing the menial tasks of other departments. You will not be doing anything technical. The job is now customer service. They have implemented to new scale, which means no more raises. You will be taking calls, chats, and emails simultaneously. You will required to complete tasks that take approx. 2 min. in 30 secs time meaning another call will be coming through. They have combined us with Registars which means you are getting yelled at daily for something you have no control over and cannot fix.

review_title: Kaplan University Indianapolis - Company Good, Management Bad
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The company promotes volunteering, which is excellent. They also try to have open communication, so there are many meetings where we can watch videos on what's happening.
cons: The management team there talks badly about other employees to other employees, they complain about one another behind each other's backs and they discriminate based on age. If you're young, you will be expected to do much of the workload while older staff can relax more. One member of management was never even in the office because she felt like "working from home" every week. Another was able to slack on deadlines while the younger ones would get a firm talking to if they weren't met. Special privileges given to older staff members and those "favorited", others must comply by the rules. Some members of management didn't care about the ideas of other employees, they just wanted to be controlling.

review_title: Great place to work, if you can't find anywhere else.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: The best reason to work at Kaplan is that they will actually hire you.  They hire EVERYONE.  They give you a shot for about 3 months and you either make it or you don't.  If you're struggling to find a job in sales, they'll give you a salary while you look for something else.
cons: They bill it as a sales job, but you get none of the benefits of being in sales. i.e. commission, time off when you want, freedom to work independently.  You DO however get to put up with cheesy sales floor tactics - rah rah meetings everyday, pointless "games" with no spiffs attached, daily pressure from management. - not a sales job, just a holding pattern. Also, if you are looking to move in to management, you better come in as such.  Over 90% of management is brought in from outside sources.

review_title: Kaplan is claiming to change but hasn't that much.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: If you can get employment outside of Admissions, then it should be a great opportunity.  If you are able to get employed right now, at least it's a job with better pay than unemployment.
cons: Tremendous amount of micromanagement with you being monitored in all accounts of the job.  Calls are closely monitored and if you make mistakes, no second chances are given (hence the revolving door).  They have no problems firing employees no matter how long they have worked for the company, even for petty mistakes.  Many of the management staff still continue to put high amounts of pressure on the advisors to sell, sell, sell.  You are expected to follow a strict schedule that is given to you weekly telling you when to take breaks and lunch.

review_title: Good place to work only if you can sell
job_title: Admissions Representative in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Kaplan university is a nice environment to work. Everyone at the work place is super nice and very helpful. The management is very flexible about schedule and time off as long as you can produce as in sell education.
cons: Kaplan university is a revolving door, they are always hiring and always firing. When they hire you they give you a three month time period to make a minimum number of sales and if you can not cut it they will fire you after three months. As such it is not uncommon to see your whole team get fired and you get left with new hires. The recruiters tell you that if you can not sell they will shift you over to a different position but that is a lie and you will be fired if the numbers are not met.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: If there are any, none come to mind.
cons: Production is king. Whether you're doing the best thing for the student or not is secondary. Your numbers are more important. Poor leads . . . these are folks that are, for the most part, looking for work and led to believe, by the aggregaters, that they are in the right place. The advisor is then supposed to get them into school. Finally, until the very end, management led everyone to believe that they were not going to close the site. They even lied to all of us.

review_title: It's not about the Student, it's about the Numbers
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: There is the opportunity to make upwards of 6 figures. However of the 1500-2000 admissions advisors there are less than 10 in the company. Benefits from day 1 and the opportunity to take apart of the Gift of Knowledge which is free education after 30 days. This includes the Masters program if you have a bachelors already.
cons: It's a numbers game. Pressure tactics to enroll students. Encouraged to come in on your day off if you are behind in your numbers otherwise your job will be on the line. Micro managed on every thing you do. Strict adherence to breaks and given lunch times. Favoritism in promotions and no clear path on how to move up. If you boss likes you than you are given a shot.

job_title: Education Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: An opportunity to learn about the online college and ever expanding education industry, has pretty good benefits.  The work life balance is good.  If you love people it gives you the opportunity to have a positive impact on people, by building relationships and helping them to achieve their career goals through higher education.
cons: As the economy suffered, like many companies they've learned to run on a leaner staff.  The day to day task are extremely out of line and don't commiserate with the salary.   They've gotten away from the culture that challenged you, but left you feeling fulfilled.  There is a workhorse mentality that doesn't do well to show appreciation in valuable ways that make their employees feel truly appreciated.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The students are wonderful and work hard. Some instructors forget that this is not a brick and mortar institution, but a school where the students, have many other obligations. They are parents, employees with many having more than 2 jobs, grandparents, some are still taking care of their own and grandkids, etc . . So, they do deserve extra consideration and they pay a lot of money for the classes.
cons: The school is making a lot of money on each student, but keeps the adjuncts at a max of $2600/per class of 24. Most of the classes have way more students, but you are only incrementally raised by a $100 over 30/class and similar for more. You can max out at 40/class and may only make $2800/class. Adjuncts receive no bennies and it is less costly for the school to hire them, and their is a large pool of applicants to choose from.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros:
-Decent Pay
-Decent Product behind you
-Interesting Coworkers surrounding you
-Good Pit Stop on your way to another career
cons:
-Can be very stressful
-Leadership (Above the site level) do not convey strength or motivate staff 
-Supervisors at all levels tend to be disconnected at times
-Communications has always been and will probably always be a bad part of Kaplan University
-Lack of growth opportunities (has been improved a little as of Summer 2012)
-Misleading marketing makes the job a lot more stressful and even poses internal moral debate when your job (implied) is a bait and switch.  
-Non Stop rumors of Orlando getting shut down and layoffs really bring the morale down.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The health benefits are great and they are somewhat flexible with scheduling. You can start as early as 6:30 AM if you prefer and sometimes management will buy lunch for the team.
cons: Managers will yell in your face at meetings, even if you are sitting right next to them. People were afraid to ask questions after the first 3 meetings and I was there for a year. Managers play favorites and will threaten to fire employees at least once a week. There is a high turnover rate. Promotions happen because of this high turnover rate, not because someone is competent. They are now Purdue Global, maybe the people are better since I've left.

review_title: Phoenix admissions is an excellent place to work.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Clear direction from local management, good team atmosphere and realistic individual goals.  Local management is very open and honest about both the process and results of the organization.
cons: Kaplan is HQ in Florida.  The HQ organization is highly fractured, seems to be operating in a panic mode and every policy and every issue seems to require an extended review by the legal department before anything can be done.  Senior management is very territorial and risk averse and the net result is that while local management in Phoenix is consistent, open and honest, the level of confusion on virtually everything to do with the state of the business coming from Florida makes it almost impossible to understand where the business is going and what the mode of operations will be at any given time.

job_title: Military Admission Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Was a paycheck and it taught me what a terrible company is.
cons:
Everything! The management did not care about any of their employees. They looked for ways to fire you. The favoritism and corruption was rampart. Some of the things that thee company directed the managers to enforce upon the admission were out right illegal. One of my bosses had no college degree and a thug mentality, she should have never been allowed to be employed at a so called university while never having gone to one herself. My other boss was a "yes man" to upper management with a napoleon complex, he would throw you under the bus right in front of you. We were given a what to say to reporters when the for profit industry got caught doing un-ethical business practices. 

 It is by far the worst company and I do not know how they are still in business. DO NOT work there unless you are about to be homeless, but have an exit plan.

review_title: Kaplan is where good professors go to whither on the vine
job_title: Professor in Davenport, IA
pros: In the beginning Kaplan was a great place to work. That is when the academics were in charge and the focus was on the education part rather than the profit part. That has changed drastically.
cons: Professors at Kaplan have absolutely no academic freedom whatsoever. The curriculum and teaching is all "canned" and controlled not by academics but by the coorporate side. The classes are so automated that professors really could stop showing up for weeks and the students wouldn't even notice it. Professors do not create the assignments, nor the exams, nor select the books, or any other part of the course. Professors at Kaplan don't teach, they are just renting out their credentials. It is all controlled by the man/woman behind the curtain.

review_title: Started out as a flexible, employee-supportive organization and turned into a corporate shell masquerading as a school
job_title: Administrative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Stable employment (if you hold to their ideas of 'service' to your customers, er, students -- and don't make waves in trying to point out the differences in management of a business versus success of a school).
cons: Limited (read: almost no) advancement opportunities, no incentive for employees to remain loyal to the company, hypocritical management, being a cog in a giant machine that only functions to take money from its educustomers.

review_title: A college created by lawyers to manipulate government funding...
job_title: Associate Director of Admissions in Boca Raton, FL
pros: I made over 100K per year..
cons:
I defrauded the government and everyone I sold this program too.  

My wife at the time told me to look at our life and out home... it was all funded by financial aid.

Kaplan executives will argue that they are giving educational/career opportunities to people who would not normally have them.  The truth is Kaplan University sought out the most financially destitute people regardless of whether they were prepared for college because our politically correct government will unbiased-ly pay for education.

From VP's snorting cocaine to commission based compensation for 9 years I saw it all.

I was as guilty as anyone.  I feel dirty thinking about it.

I learned a lesson in karma and I now live with principle and integrity at the forefront of my life.  I owe Kaplan in a way.  I've experienced the dregs of humanity from top to bottom.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros:
Teaches you how to multi-task
Multiple training opportunities and programs
Free tuition
Great benefits
Competitive Salary
cons:
Travel policy is horrible.  No corporate card. Must pay upfront to get reimbursed.
Bureaucratic promotions
Will give you a title with a job description, but have you filling in for all the roles that were laid off or fired instead of promoting you or paying you for that role
Communication is a failure;
Sneaky tactics on firing people
Will allow those who don't work to stay in their role w/ no corrective action, and make the busy bees make up for what that person doesn't do --shifting workload 
Only room for Growth in Florida offices; none in Chicago or other locations

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: You learn alot about sales and refine your sales skills. The high pressure environment can actually make you a better sales person.
cons: Always feel like you're one bad cycle away from losing your job. Job is not like any other sales position where the deal is closed and the prospect pulls out a credit card and its over. You get no credit if the student enrolls but doesnt start. These are things you cannot control. You cannot make someone start if they dont want to. Your job depends on lazy, umemployed, slackers doing their part to better themselves. High buy in required from prospects.

job_title: Financial Aid Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: If you're good with corporate politics might be good for you. I was promoted 3 times within 2.5 years.
cons: Management has no idea what they are doing. They promote people with no management experience and expect them to run teams of 10+ employees. In the time I worked for the Financial Aid department they changed HR contacts 6 times in 2.5 years so that if you had to complain you could never get a hold of anyone. If your manager didn't like you they WILL find a way to fire you. Teams are poorly trained and training team really doesn't know Financial Aid regulations or company policies. Each location - Fort Lauderdale, Orlando, and Chicago all do different things and hate each other. Company values are a joke. Students don't come first and never will. If you make it at this company for more then a year you'll be wondering how this company is still in business.

review_title: Just an amazing place to work!
job_title: Tech Support in Orlando, FL
pros: The atmosphere is absolutely amazing. One of the best call center environments I've ever been in. What makes this job great is the people. You make friends that'll last a lifetime and the resources provided by management are wonderful. If you have the desire to do well a manager will take you under their wing to help you reach your career goals.
cons: Things change in the education industry very quickly and it seemed like Kaplan fell behind the competition regarding optimizing mobile platforms. They've just recently got on the ball about it but they still have a lot of work to do.

review_title: This company will chew you up and spit you out
job_title: Instructional Designer in Chicago, IL
pros: Few: some employees can work from home, hours were not monitored and I was generally not micromanaged
cons: Toxic work environment, terrible corporate culture, extreme top-down management, no communication from higher up whether it's company benefit changes or raises or your new boss or your day to day work. I was on a need-to-know basis. Your job description can change on a dime. Egomaniacal managers are allowed to run amok. Different employees in the same division, even with the same job title, can have wildly different job duties, salaries and perks depending upon who their manager is. It is not a meritocracy: good work is not rewarded, only sucking up. No opportunity for advancement. Extreme focus on the bottom line--which is not that unusual, but this is an EDUCATION provider. All the best people bailed. The Chicago office couldn't keep an HR director for more than 8 months. Can't believe they're still in business.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company does a lot of community work and makes it a point to recognize outstanding employees.
cons: Employee experience and recognition depends heavily on direct supervisors. Although there are employee surveys, it doesn't seem that the leadership is truly paying attention to what employees are saying.  This results in department heads who are taking advantage of their control, and employees who would otherwise have a lot to offer being stifled by management.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Plantation, FL
pros: Benefits are good, and you get to take classes for free, but the education you receive is not of quality at all.
cons: The admissions advisor position at Kaplan University is a pure sales position. If you think that you are going to be working in academia, think again. It is a high pressure sales environment with an extremely uneven playing filed where nepotism and favoritism are at their maximum level. If the management happen to like you (for whatever reason), then you are in luck, there is nothing that you can do wrong, even if you don't hit your sales goal, they will figure out a way to keep you. BUT, if you are not a favorite, either because you refuse to lie on the phone to perspective students, or refuse to mislead people on the phone, then good luck.  This is not a professional job for someone who is college educated. Do not waste your time with them.

job_title: Student Accounts Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Compensation not too bad and a free education.
cons: Management, employee drama, and favoritism. No training of any kind and backward computer programs which have constant issues.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Plantation, FL
pros: I've been here for a decade and Kaplan has always taken care of me and my family. Kaplan has fair pay, good benefits, a friendly work environment (especially if you are successful), and many of the Directors make an active effort to help you improve. The Gift of Knowledge program is awesome...I earned a Masters degree for the cost of the textbooks.
cons: I've seen a lot of people come and go through the years, but that's with any challenging job. Its definitely not for everyone. Not every advisor has the skills and ability motivate a student to begin their classes in an expensive program like ours. If you cannot

job_title: Senior Military Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Benefits package from Washington Post was strong compared to most proprietary schools. Has a true pension plan if you can last more than three years. Health insurance is tiered based on your salary. Work life was descent. Nothing from work to bring home. When you are finished for the day, you are finished for the day.
cons: Call center environment/ Online programs are too easy with questionable educational results. Overall atmosphere was high pressure sales to clients and representatives.  You live by the time clock as every possible metric is measured, analyzed and used to "train you" Bathroom breaks are timed by Orion. If you are gone to long you will have a conversation with your DOA or ADOA when you return.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Ability to teach online. Good curriculum design. The pay is reasonable, given the responsibilities.
cons: Kaplan University is trying to avoid the federal scrutiny, but also do anything they can to let their students be successful - including cheat. They put in place policies which allow the students to learn how to fake the plagiarism checkers, and also penalize (or get rid of) faculty who object to the policy or don't allow their students to "try again" when they turn in plagiarized material.

review_title: Great Perks but not great for an admissions advisor
job_title: Admissions Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Nice Perks, like health benefits, employee cafe, everyone tries to stay positive
cons: If you are an admissions advisor, be prepared to work 60 hours/week with no overtime to meet your goals. You will be viewed as a "cog in the machine" and they will quickly replace you if you are not performing. There is no work-life balance, if you have to leave early take a personal day be prepared to be guilt-tripped as to why you shouldn't take time off. Be prepared to call prospective students on the day after thanksgiving and Christmas eve.

review_title: Solid Company but a bit confused on direction
job_title: Director in Parkland, FL
pros:
Solid financial backers
mid level employees and managers are hard workers
student best interest at heart
cons:
To conservative at times
upper leadership between departments dont speak enough
change of strategy to often
no local community ties

job_title: Sharepoint Developer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The office location on Cypress Creek is very nice, new and clean. They have a great on-site cafeteria. The two covered parking garages for employee use are a plus. Most of the employees I interacted with or observed at this office seemed young and energetic.
cons: Lack of technical leadership was a major cause of concern.  In my case it was the primary reason for terminating my contract.  Millions of dollars are recklessly spent on SharePoint technology without giving the proper training to the team that needs to support the investment.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company has a lot of long time employees. Albeit, there is a good amount of attrition among new hires. If you are looking to move upward within this organization, you better be very competitive and ready to drink the kool-aide. Dress code is casual. Jeans and t-shirts are the norm.
cons: Lack of upward mobility. Highly competitive environment to get ahead, you better be a golfing buddy or be friends with the CEO. Lack of qualified leads

review_title: Admissions Advisor for more than 4 years
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Some pretty cool co-workers- peers. At first, really felt like helping students change their lives,  The school/education itself matches that goal, but just too expensive.
cons: Have never worked for a corporation, that day in and day out , made me feel my job was going to be just swept away. Except for a few supervisors , never worked for a more inept group of self serving flunkies in my life. Numbers, numbers, numbers- pushed by used car salesmen ( and women !). Goals changing every 2-3 months, but with a lead operation that is clueless.. not sure how it has lasted this long, but it was a paycheck!!

job_title: in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The best reason to work at Kaplan is the salary range which is fair compared to the national average.
cons: Kaplan does not have a standard they go by as far as training or changes in the company.  They do not listen to or care about employee or student feedback on how to make changes or improvements.  Kaplan's only concernis about the bottom dollar and numbers not a positive image with students or faculty.

job_title: Student Loan Counselor/Mail Research Specialist in Harvey, IL
pros: I enjoyed the interaction with the students on providing and giving them an opportunity to get their student loans in order..They wanted to do what was right most of the time, but at times they needed more coaching on what the impact of what this could be to them later on down the road.
cons: The students felt mislead about what they had signed up for, it was not explained to them as to what they had committed to. I felt for them and tried to reassure them they have to push forward.

review_title: Hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Assisting different people achieve through education. Company provides free education. Diverse co-workers. Great sales training. Academic offerings are very good.
cons: Business and Academics don't know what the other is doing. Business Leaders from the president down, runs the company like an assembly factory. Individual thought or ideas are frowned upon. This is a job speed bump to most. No career growth. Company values are a show.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: The consultative sales techniques you're taught are easily transferrable to other positions and the ability to take classes for another degree are nice.
cons: Where do I start. The calls are sent to you from another call center who is just trying to hit their numbers of calls transferred. These people filled something out saying they may be interested in pursuing higher education while browsing facebook or applying for jobs because they're out of work. These people are typically lazy and won't help you hit the insane sales goals set for you every month. Management has no idea what the hell they're doing as policies seem to change every day. The price of a bachelors degree from an online college shouldn't be $64000. That is predatory.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Town Line, NY
pros: On-line learning tools are powerful and it's possible to develop real relationships with students. Some of the faculty are excellent and care about everything they do.
cons: There is no opportunity for growth or advancement. The school's business model is based on not paying faculty a fair rate. I am working more hours today than I was three years ago for about 40% less pay. Although I enjoy much of what I do for Kaplan University I feel as if I am being cruelly taken advantage of.

job_title: Team Lead-Admission Advisor in Plantation, FL
pros: Kaplan supports employees who strive to do well and work on improving your skills. I had a great experience working with them. Not only do they offer free education, but they stand by you when your in school. The work load is absolutely overwhelming at times, but if you work hard at perfecting your craft, skills and success, they will assist you in becoming the best advisor on your team.
cons: Minimum cons, they do micromanage at times, and pick on aspects of your day that could be overlooked, but overall it is to simply improve productivity.

review_title: Pay ok, Company and benefits ok, beware of layoffs
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plantation, FL
pros: Kaplan University is an employer that gives its employees very good wages. The pay is good as are the benefits. Benefits include health, dental, and enrollment discounts should you wish to take classes. The overall environment of the job can be fun and celebratory at times. While you are there you feel appreciated.
cons: The company has unfortunately been going through layoffs for the past three years. Management does its best to puts employees at ease, and if you are laid off the company still does it's best to help you.

review_title: Great Company to Work for Depending on Where You Get In...
job_title: Temporary Assistant in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
The Fort Lauderdale location has a cafateria with reasonable pricing!
The Facility is very nice with 2 very large parking garages and plenty of security
Fellow Employees generally have a good attitude and are 'youthful' and light hearted, but respectful.
Lots of room for advancement. Kaplan promotes from within and they actually mean it! Once you've been with the company as a permanent employee for 6months, you're free to apply to other divisions with the approval of your manager.


If you get in through a temp agency, you have the ability to work directly under Directors and upper management. I was assigned to work at Kaplan for a 2 week assignment and it's turned into several months. If you dress appropriately, work very hard and carry yourself well, they'll take interest in you and keep you on for much longer. They've already mentioned about bringing me on permanently and it's only been a few months! But not everyone is hired on this way.So be warned!
cons: It's a business. No matter if you're running a Business, a Church, or a non-profit company, MONEY is going to eventually come up. Kaplan is focused around it, as they should since they're growing exponentially. If you get into this company as a Admissions Advisor, be ready to WORK! It's typically an out-bound call type job, but they're usually warm leads--meaning these people have requested more information and it's your job to screen them and try to sell the school to the prospective student should they be made of 'the right stuff'. It can be very frustrating because there are a lot of lazy students that just want a degree. There's a lot of scum bags who'll never call you back, or give you the run around. You're held responsible for meeting numbers of calls, interviews, emails, and enrollments.

review_title: Thankful I Don't Work There Anymore
job_title: Full Time Faculty in South Portland, ME
pros: I liked working at Kaplan University at first - great co-workers, enthusiastic students, flexible hours and decent pay and benefits.
cons: There is no local control, everything, including what instructors do in their classrooms (down to the quizzes and assignments given) is dictated by corporate employees who have never stepped foot in a classroom. The local management is vindictive. Overall it is run like a business not a school and it looks out for its own business interests, not the best interests of students and staff. There is no communication between departments and no job security.

review_title: Great people, not so great school
job_title: Academic Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros:
Pay is competitive for the experience that they require.  
Office is in a great location in the West Loop and is easy to get to by public transportation.
cons: Emphasis was not placed on the student and helping them succeed but on enrollment numbers and in advocating for degree programs that weren't fully staffed with teachers to teach the curriculum.  Turnover was also high with the occasional mass lay-off.

review_title: Kaplan University in the Grad Psych program
job_title: Adjnct in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great supervisors, good support, great teaching and learning center, good professor education,  a family type of feeling, supervisors care about the professor's experience, great company conferences, opportunity to get more involved in the company activities, offers gift of education and discount for family members.
cons: sometimes there are not enough students in certain tracks, so if not full time, can go months without a class.  Compensation could be better.

job_title: Education Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great co-workers, benefits are ok.
cons: Leadership is terrible at all levels: no management skills, treat people like commodities; some are uneducated and many promoted past their edge of competence, which they try to cover up by micromanaging. Kaplan's moral compass broke many years ago. Professional development opportunities are slim to none; morale is non-existent. Most people stay because they have become complacent. Employees are expected to be like little worker bees- pound out the phone calls and make sure to hit their daily metrics.

review_title: Great Company to learn about all steps of admissions I worked for about one year as an Admissions Sales Representative.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The training is excellent and continuous to success. This is no doubt a team orientated Company. There is some flexibility as long as you keep up with training and work heard. You have to enjoy working with a large company of well over 100 in one area.
cons: Metrics are sometimes difficult to meet. Often time it can depend on the team you are on and your mentor from the beginning is so important.

review_title: Kaplan is a sinking ship laying off many
job_title: Human Resources in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Good, hardworking coworkers. The people are mostly great to work with.
cons: There is no job security because Kaplan stil lays off people in large numbers due to never recovering from controversy and they continue to make poor decisions. The politics are overwhelming and the favoritism is sad. Recently, they remodeled the executive suite instead of investing in ways to retain disappearing students. Kaplan operates like a business and not a school. Little emphasis is placed on the students. Poor communication and senseless business practices have left employees overworked and frustrated. Don't expect to get promoted unless you're one of the favorites.

review_title: A complete whirlwiind as Management did not know what they were doing.
job_title: Chair In the Business Area in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
* work in remote therefore, you do not have your boss on top of you all the time.
* if you do a good job they leave you alone.
* the best position is to be an instructor.
cons:
* changes for the sake of change.
* management ranks were not stable, they changed constantly and everyone had a different vision.
* few opportunities for advancement.
* management does not want to hear new ideas.
* management's mentality is completely as in traditional colleges where instructors do not participate.
* very few praises given for work well done.
* strong emphasis in the bottom line instead of building quality programs.
* any management responsibility you take exposes you to retaliation if you do not conform.

review_title: Great for innovation and personal growth but always at the expense of employees work-life balance (imbalance)
job_title: Curriculum and Innovation in Chicago, IL
pros: Awesome place to learn and achieve personal growth. Truly cares about students and providing the best possible service.  Students definitely benefit and earn their degree in a nurturing and well designed environment. Company always has a student focus. Benefits are generally good.
cons: Work life balance is horrible for employees. The amount of work expectation is never considered when requiring new projects.  Being a virtual company seems to allow the company to ignore the constant unrealistic demands that are put on employees and this is never considered when asking for more out of employees. Even though there is a yearly survey to try to fix the work-balance, which indicates concern, the intention quickly becomes forgotten until the next survey a year later. This seems to be due to the desire to have the work done without wanting to obtain the resources that would make it possible. So the leaders making these decisions  forget the life balance in favor of pushing their own agendas. This has been going on for years. Most people love the company until they are just used up and have to leave to regain their life back.  Even with raises we make less and less per hour every year so leaving eventually becomes the best solution.

review_title: Kaplan University was a very challenging place to work!
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: The potential salary could be very attractive and aggressive.
cons: Higher salary also translated to higher goals and could very easily mean losing your position if you could not meet those goals. The company doesn't treat it's employee's very well and pressures them to perform which leads to fraud.

job_title: Military Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Loved my coworkers they were pretty much the only thing that made it bearable. Since all the lead my team received were burnt out the minute we got them we spend our days being hung up on and threatened the second we called them because they had already gotten tons of phone calls every day.
cons: Leads were burnt out the minute I got them so the chances of my making my goals were very slim.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
Keeps Faculty aware of changes with communication
Flexibility as an online faculty member
Various scholarship opportunities
cons:
Earning less while KU expects more (literally had an opportunity to teach 2 classes twice during the 10 years of being employed.)
Limited diversity in upper management
Limited opportunity for growth within KU (they overload with adjuncts and have limited full-time faculty members).

job_title: Director in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
Good benefits, including free education
Good people - it depends where you land
cons:
Culture of paranoia, delusion, dense politics and double standards.
They hire very smart people and not listen to them, eventually they leave, its a revolving door, its the opposite of the Apple culture.
They hire VP, Senior VPs and the like in hope that they will solve the problems, they dont, they dont even make decisions, in the meantime, they need real people to solve problems.

review_title: Great place to work.. Horrible upper management staff
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Great employee benfits and great people to work with!
cons: Upper management has turned higher education into a sweat shop. More emphasis is placed on numbers than quality of students. Horrible leads are provided, byt advisors are expected to convince anyone to go to school. Management is not held accountable when ineffective decisions are made,  yet advisors are held accountable for unattainable goals, which can cost them their job if not met on a month by month basis..

job_title: Admissions Advisor II in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Nice physical plant, free parking
cons: Poor management in the admissions department. Everything is done ATM. ATM means AT THE MOMENT. Very little is any advance warning of internal desk relocation or department moves until the very last moment. A floating lunch schedule that dictates your lunch today might be at noon , tomorrow at 2:00 the day after at 11:30 and following day at 4:00pm.

review_title: At least I got a paycheck
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Greenbelt, MD
pros: Not much in the positive to say.  There were some excellent teachers who genuinely wanted to educate the students.
cons:
Everything bad you hear about for-profit schools are true.  Classrooms with not enough or the right equipment,  books showing up weeks after a class begins, outdated or broken learning materials, admitting students who are unable to pay or admit students who should not be there.  There were students who could not do basic math, students who could barely read or write, students who were there because a judge ordered them to go to school or they would have to go to jail.  Constant mandatory meetings that were unpaid.  

The list could go on and on and on...

review_title: Kaplan is why teachers quit teaching
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Greenbelt, MD
pros:
I would like to say Kaplan provides students the ability to learn a profession and skills to advance in the real world...  For a select few, it does.
There are teachers there who genuinely care for their work and their students.
cons:
The school didnt provide the materials needed for class.
The school admitted students who could not afford to attend.
The school admitted students who were uneducated - they could barely do basic math, read or write.
The school admitted students who did not want to be there - I had students that were ordered to attend by a court.
The school hired teachers who were not qualified to teach the subjects they were teaching.
The school required teachers to do hours of unpaid work per day.
The list goes on and on...

review_title: Avoid working for Kaplan University at all costs!!!
job_title: Military Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: The people that you work with on your team, the people on your level, not the high and mighty managers.
cons: The management, from Associate Directors all the way up the chain, it seems that the management team has zero idea of how to treat their employees with respect. They focus only on numbers and treat people like expendable trash. The strange thing is that the high paid managers are not held accountable for sales numbers, only the advisors are, and are given three strikes and then they are out, literally.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plantation, FL
pros: Excellent health benefits, many good people there.
cons: Too many decisions made by executives on high with little or no regard to how the front lines employees must implement them. Driven by numbers, not service, they have evolved a mediocre-call center mentality.

review_title: Enthusiastic People but Discouraging for Teachers
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The people at the Learning Center level are all enthusiastic, positive, and dedicated to student success.
cons: Curriculum is designed by corporate and not flexible enough to accommodate all types of students. Admissions procedures do not take into account whether students are actually prepared for college level courses. There's a real disconnect between expectations and reality.

job_title: Senior Admissions Advisor in Miami, FL
pros: Good health benefits, and PTO . Ability to make a good salary and increase it in a short amount of time. You meet great people from many different walks of life.
cons: Salary can change every six months and you can go from making $ 90 K to $ 30K  just that fast. There can be favoritism and you can be set up for success or failure. You will have to at least one weekend day and some nights.

job_title: Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Casual atmosphere, including casual dress. Young, fun staff. Lots of opportunities for lateral movements to other departments. Decent benefits - health, dental, 401K, discounts.
cons: Senior leadership is very disconnected from the day-to-day and makes knee-jerk decisions to make massive changes without taking into account the impact or requirements of bringing that change to fruition, which leads to a stressful environment where necessary tools are often not yet available or not effective. Leadership driven by politics rather than competence.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: Remote work environment... the convenience of working from home can't be beat. Helping students is one of the greatest feelings one can hope to experience, no matter what educational institution you work for.
cons: "Leadership" is very arrogant and constantly promotes how great they are and how Kaplan is a "GREAT PLACE". Ever hear the saying... "a fish stinks from the head"? This is the case in both academics and curriculum. They can care less about the faculty! The pure arrogance of the Deans and Chairs is like no other educational institution! This is a "For-Profit" organization and office politics rules the day!

review_title: Not a bad place to work as a part-time college student or recent grad.
job_title: Admissions Advisor II in Orlando, FL
pros: The pay is pretty lucrative if you're working through your degree while you're employed. They try to show employees their graditude through formal lunch functions that are catered by elite groups.
cons: No potential for upward movement. Pay is stagnent because of the new laws on for profit schools. The industry is dying and probably won't be around long.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Plantation, FL
pros:
Fun working with peers at times
Very fulfilling working with students because you're making a difference
Good job to have if transitioning jobs
cons:
High rate of turnover (about every 6 months there is a mass firing)
Stressful to meet quotas
Department and individual goals constantly changing which sometimes puts you in the less favorable position
Job is never secure
Care about profits over employes 
Management deceives employees that it will be a new prosperous career but its a people mill

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Wonderful co-worker's, descent pay at the time, good benefits.
cons: Unstable work environment, rules changed too frequently.  You'd be trained over and over again as the policies and job function changed at least every month, sometimes more often.  Everything was monitored, measured and evaluated.  Big Brother was watching every move.  This is a high pressure sales job.  Think twice before accepting a position.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Chicago, IL
pros: Great colleagues and flexibility to work from home
cons:
I never had less than a great review from my dean or assistant dean and had high marks on reviews from my students for 7 years.  Then enrollment drops and they don't even explain why you cannot get a class --- ever.  I finally found something else but communication after 7 years would be the classy thing to do.
Also the live webinars every week HAD to be in the evening, which was a drag.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Generally good students, reasonably decent pay, more relaxed pace with ten-week classes.

Less administrative/grading burden than others (Phoenix, et al.)
cons: Rules that change - unlike Phoenix et al, there are no clear and hard and fast rules about student assignment submissions, grading policy, etc.  Heaven help you if you're "late" in grading, but students must be "accommodated" at all costs including submitting work weeks late, ridiculous hand-holding of adults, etc.

job_title: Program Director in Fresno, CA
pros: The corporation takes care of their employees.  If you have a concern, you can approach management at anytime and if your request is reasonable, most of the time you will be accommodated.
cons: Policy.  I came from a law enforcement background where policy was the standard.  Not to say that their is no policy, it is just not readily accessible like law enforcement.

review_title: Admissions Advisor: Decent pay for the work that is expected.
job_title: Admssions Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: This is a great job to get a steady paycheck and benefits, don't expect to get rich.  Don't be afraid of layoffs, they have previously been very fair with giving notice and compensation.
cons: Career progression is limited.  You can move up, but you can't move down, so if you want to promote, be prepared to perform at a much higher level.

job_title: Recruiter in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: I worked in the recruiting department - I worked with a great team. The environment was fun but we knew what needed to be done. The company has an onsite cafeteria as well as a small gym that employees can us during breaks or before/after work. Salary was fair and was able to take college classes while working there.
cons: Nothing I can think of - great place for recruiters to work. You have to have some recruiting experience, I wouldn't recommend the position for someone new to recruiting as it is a fast paced environment.

review_title: Best Company I have ever worked
job_title: Admissions Associate in Plantation, FL
pros: Kaplan University is very professional and corporate environment, yet very comfortable to work as an employee and fun.  They care about their employees. Although not a lot of incentives, there is enough to make you want to stay. Their health benefits are great as well, good working hours and wonderful staff including management.  Best place I have ever worked in the USA.
cons: Like any other job, the sales aspect of it, if you are not meeting your goals, then you will eventually lose your job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plantation, FL
pros:
1.  GREAT PEOPLE- if you come in with the right attitude and aren't afraid to work
2.  Work/Life- they really try there best to help make your life as easy as possible
3.  Free College
4. Independence- if you work hard they will not micro manage you.
cons:
1. Advancement- Unless you fit into quota categorizes you will NOT advance here
2. Pay- if you haven't done sales before its pretty good- but once you learn then you can make money else where

review_title: Only if you are absolutely desparate
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Co-workers (excluding management) were great.  Most everyone was on the same page.  Pay was decent, but not great.
cons:
Management was very poor.  They are big on you seeking out additional training, but never respond to requests.  Minimum requirements (usually 3 students per month) are unrealistic.  Those minimums are set to the average number of students per year, however you are only allowed to miss minimum requirements 3 times per year.  Statistically it just doesn't work.

Moreover the training does not prepare you for the reality of the job.  In reality it is hard sales, but trainers and recruiters lead you to believe it is customer service.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company has some of the best benefits (health, dental, PTO, etc.) I have had. The dress code is very casual (T-Shirts and jeans are ok).
cons: Absolutely no job security. The company seems to focus more on writing employees up and setting unrealistic goals that are not attainable. They obviously fire employees constantly and then just hire new ones to replace those who have been lost.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The best thing about Kaplan is the great people that work there. They are a group of talented and intelligent people.
cons: Pure sales environment. It used to be a great place to work and then new VP took over and now morale is at an all time low and of course they blame the front line staff,  as they always do. It's really disheartening how much they do not value their employees.

review_title: A perfect job for me right now
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Completely online, never have to leave my home to attend meetings or teach house, no need to commute, arrange childcare, etc. Most of the students are wonderful and very diligent.
cons: The pay for large classes is the same as for much smaller classes. Same pay for 9 students as 30. Some of the students are not prepared.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Great benefits, wonderful coworkers who really care about each other and the students.  Nice work environment.
cons: Leads come in too slowly, too much down time which makes the day drag.  Hi pressure for sales  and employee is made to account for situation over which he no control.  One month you can be on top, the next fearful of your job.  Your job depends on stacked rankings.

job_title: Admissions Representative in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: U are in Florida, the best part of the day is gettin to take a step outside. I had to remind myself I had always wanted to live in Florida
cons: U Got to sell someone what they may or may not want and u know it's fixing to create all kinds of debt in student loans, that is more pain than gain and Kaplan knows it

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Pompano Beach, FL
pros: I did not end up having anything good to say about them once I got through the training program.
cons: Cold hearted company - you are expected to make people feel so bad about themselves that they are left feeling they will never amount to anything if they don't register for one of the healthcare programs. Sad really. You are encouraged to NOT be friends with fellow workers - to be an island to yourself for fear that if your friend has a bad experience, it will in turn affect you. Hated working there and have heard from other employers that they hear the same stories from other previous Kaplan employees. Makes you go, "Hmmmmmmmmmm."

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Good people employed here, you won't find better. Good benefits, work/life balance. Job is not difficult.
cons: No job security. Goals impossible to attain consistently month in and month out. For-profit universities declining in enrollment (non profits are now playing in this on-line space) so leads are poor. You can be a top performer and still lose your job.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: It is good for those very early in their academic career.  It can provide some online experience.
cons: Lots of touchy feely and unnessary trainings on things that experienced college professors know.
